confusion_pairs.title: Threat Vector vs Attack Surface

a.definition: What can be attacked (exposed systems, ports, services).

b.definition: How the attacker gets in (phishing, USB, wireless, supply chain).

bullets: Surface = targetable exposure; vector = path of entry.
A USB drop is a vector; the endpoint is the surface.

confusion_pairs.title: Internal vs External Threat Actors

a.definition: Actor already has authorized access or is inside the org.

bullets: Insiders often need less initial access work.
External actors rely more on vectors for entry.
Motivation can be similar across both.

confusion_pairs.title: OSINT vs Closed/Proprietary Intel

b.definition: Paid, vendor, or government-curated intel feeds.

bullets: OSINT is open but can be noisy.
Closed intel often has higher curation and context.
Both should be scored for confidence.

confusion_pairs.title: STIX vs TAXII
bullets: STIX describes the data; TAXII moves it.

confusion_pairs.title: Hacktivist vs Nation-State
bullets: Hacktivists seek visibility; APTs seek long-term advantage.
Nation-state actors are typically more resourced.
Both can target critical infrastructure but motives differ.

vector_message.rule: Message-based vectors include email/SMS/IM/voice social engineering.
vector_message.micro_example: A phishing email is a message-based vector.

vector_supply_chain.rule: Supply chain attacks abuse vendors, MSPs, or update mechanisms.
vector_supply_chain.micro_example: Compromised software update server delivers malware.

vector_removable.rule: Removable media vectors include USB drops and external drives.
vector_removable.micro_example: An infected USB left in a parking lot is removable media.

actor_insider.rule: Insider threats already have authorized access.
actor_insider.micro_example: A disgruntled admin exporting customer data is insider.

actor_nation_state.rule: Nation-state actors are highly resourced and persistent.
actor_nation_state.micro_example: A multi-month espionage campaign suggests APT.

actor_orgcrime.rule: Organized crime focuses on profit-driven cybercrime.
actor_orgcrime.micro_example: Ransomware deployed for payout is organized crime.

ti_osint.rule: OSINT is public intel; verify confidence before use.
ti_osint.micro_example: A public GitHub repo with IoCs is OSINT.

ti_closed.rule: Closed intel is paid or curated by vendors/government.
ti_closed.micro_example: A vendor feed with attribution and scoring is closed.

ti_stix_taxii.rule: STIX is the format; TAXII is the transport.
ti_stix_taxii.micro_example: Your SIEM ingests STIX over TAXII.

ti_confidence.rule: Confidence scoring rates how timely, accurate, and relevant intel is.
ti_confidence.micro_example: Low-confidence intel gets extra verification before action.
